chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Julie A. Wantz was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: shall be installed on any motor vehicle owned and/or operated by defendant.
Defendant shall undergo an AODA Assessment and follow through with any recommendations resulting therefrom.

miscConds.notes: Defenant to pay fine, costs, blood draw fee and DNA surcharge within the term of probation. Defendant to pay costs of supervision.

Defendant shall not use/possess/control any controlled substances (without a valid prescription therefore) or drug paraphernalia, nor be in the presence of anyone who does.

Defendant shall not consume alcohol or other intoxicants.  Defendant must maintain absolute sobriety and shall not go upon the premises of any establishment whose primary business activity involves the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, including bars, taverns, liquor stores and beer tents.

Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle unless he has a valid Wisconsin driver's license.
Defendant must inform Agent, physician and/or physician's assistant of opiate addiction.

Defendant shall undergo an AODA Assessment and follow through with any recommendations resulting therefrom.  Defendant shall successfully attend an OWI Victim Impact Panel within 120 days of conviction.

timeConds.notes:
in Dodge County Jail with Huber and Transfer consecutive.
Consecutive to: any other sentence previously imposed

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Julie A. Wantz in court, in custody with attorney Joanne M. Keane.  Gilbert Grant Thompson appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Atty Keane heard, Def. now goes by last name of "Huntermark" Court reviews PQ&WOR, charges, penalties and rights. Def. pleads guilty to Ct. 1. Court heard, finds plea is made FV&K, accepts plea, finds Def. guilty of Ct. 1. Ct. 2 is DRI. Atty Thompson heard. Atty Keane heard. Def. makes statement. Court heard, imposes sent.:

3 yrs P&P
360 days DCJ w/ H&T consecutive w/ any other sentence
$600 plus cost
26 blood draw free
Not to use/poss. substance w/o RX 
Inform agent and physician and/or physician's assistant of opiate addiction
AODA and any follow through by agent
No bars; absolute sobriety
VIP w/ 120 days
36mos IID, revoke
Plea/sentencing hearing on October 27, 2014 at 03:30 pm.

Defendant Julie A. Wantz in court, in custody via video with attorney Jaclyn R. Shelton (eligible).  Gilbert Grant Thompson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.   Defendant has received copy of Criminal Complaint and advised of rights, charges, penalties and right to Preliminary Hearing. Court finds probable cause. Prelim requested within time limits. Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle without permission from this Court.  Restrictions on travel: Shall not leave the State of Wisconsin.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for October 9, 2014 at 03:00 pm.
